image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

title.children: El Niño is likely to bring a scorching summer. These cities might feel it most

image.altText: Anthony Albanese putting on a mask at a press conference.

props.synopsis: An inquiry has been announced into the state, territory and federal governments' response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.children: Government announces inquiry into federal, state and territory response to pandemic

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant nicknamed "Pirola" has been detected in Australia after sparking a sped-up vaccination program in the United Kingdom.

title.children: The 'highly mutated' COVID variant BA.2.86 — known as Pirola — has landed in Australia

image.altText: fire crews at blaze spray water on fire

props.synopsis: A petrol station has exploded into flames after gas cylinders caught alight as crews worked to save neighbouring homes in Sydney's west.

title.children: Motorist describes the moment a Sydney petrol station caught fire while he was filling up

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addresses a high level Security Council meeting.

props.synopsis: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy takes the floor at the UN Security Council to lash 'criminal' Russia before foreign secretary Sergei Lavrov unloads for Russia.

title.children: As Russia ignores Zelenskyy at UN, Ukraine calls for stripping of Russia's veto power

image.altText: Eddie Jones looks pensive after the Wallabies lost to Fiji at the 2023 Rugby World Cup.

props.synopsis: Retired Test winger Drew Mitchell blames veteran coach Eddie Jones for putting the Wallabies in danger of missing the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals for the first time.

title.children: Ex-Wallaby unloads expletive-loaded criticism on Eddie Jones as World Cup campaign hangs by a thread

image.altText: Image of crowd at music festival at sunset

props.synopsis: Yours and Owls festival organisers want attendees to vote before arriving at the event after a request for on-site voting booths was turned down.

title.children: 20,000 young people will be at this festival on the day of the Voice referendum. But will they vote?

image.altText: LeBron James stands in front of a white board.

props.synopsis: Five years ago, LeBron James set out to fix some of America's most difficult problems. Some question whether the project is living up to its promises.

title.children: LeBron James set out to revolutionise America’s broken school system. Then the results came in

image.altText: George RR Martin

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Game of Thrones author George RR Martin sues OpenAI for 'systematic theft', Australia urges US to let Julian Assange walk free. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the purpose of the government's inquiry into Australia's COVID-19 response is to better prepare for the future. "We said before the election — and I've said since — given the enormous dislocation, the stress, the loss of life, the economic impact of the pandemic, it is appropriate that when we reached a certain period that we would have an inquiry," he says. "We need to examine what could be done better, with a focus on the future. "Because the health experts and the science tells us that this pandemic may well be — indeed is — not likely to be the last one that occurs." He says support for people impacted by pandemic lockdowns will be a part of the review. Health Minister Mark Butler says it will help build the Centre for Disease Control, which will be a "very important part" of preparing for the next pandemic.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says inquiry into COVID-19 response will prepare Australia for future pandemics

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the purpose of the government's inquiry into Australia's COVID-19 response is to better prepare for the future.

"We said before the election — and I've said since — given the enormous dislocation, the stress, the loss of life, the economic impact of the pandemic, it is appropriate that when we reached a certain period that we would have an inquiry," he says.
"We need to examine what could be done better, with a focus on the future.
"Because the health experts and the science tells us that this pandemic may well be — indeed is — not likely to be the last one that occurs."
He says support for people impacted by pandemic lockdowns will be a part of the review.
Health Minister Mark Butler says it will help build
the Centre for Disease Control, which will be a "very important part" of preparing for the next pandemic.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By David Speers Former Liberal treasurer Josh Frydenberg is expected to confirm today he is not seeking a return to politics at the next election. He has taken a new position as the chair of investment bank Goldman Sachs for Australia and New Zealand. Mr Frydenberg has been with Goldman Sachs as senior regional adviser for the Asia Pacific since 2022, after he lost the Melbourne seat of Kooyong to independent Monique Ryan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former treasurer Josh Frydenberg set to announce decision not to run at next election

children.content: By David Speers
Former Liberal treasurer Josh Frydenberg is expected to confirm today he is not seeking a return to politics at the next election.
(AAP: James Ross)
He has taken a new position as the chair of investment bank Goldman Sachs for Australia and New Zealand.
Mr Frydenberg has been with Goldman Sachs as senior regional adviser for the Asia Pacific since 2022, after he lost the Melbourne seat of Kooyong to independent Monique Ryan.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What would Bob Ross think? The artist who brought painting to the people, with works completed for TV viewers in less than 30 minutes, certainly wouldn't have envisioned one of his works going up for sale for nearly $US10 million ($A16 million). But that's the price a Minneapolis gallery in the US is asking for A Walk In The Woods — the first of more than 400 paintings Ross produced on-air for his PBS series The Joy Of Painting. "It is season one, episode one of what you would call the rookie card for Bob Ross," Ryan Nelson, who owns the gallery, Modern Artifact, said of the work created in the show's debut in 1983. He says he doesn't expect a quick sale given the high asking price, which he sees as an opportunity to display the painting for a larger audience. "What this piece represents is the people's artist," Mr Nelson says. "This isn't an institution that's telling you that Bob Ross is great. It's not some high-brow gallery telling you that Bob Ross is great. This is the masses, the population in the world that are saying that Bob Ross is great." On that first show, Ross — sporting his beloved perm, full beard and unbuttoned shirt — stressed that painting didn't need to be pretentious: Ross, who died in 1995, hosted the show until 1994.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'The people's artist': First Bob Ross TV painting goes on sale for nearly $16 million

children.content: What would Bob Ross think?

The artist who brought painting to the people, with works completed for TV viewers in less than 30 minutes, certainly wouldn't have envisioned one of his works going up for sale for nearly $US10 million ($A16 million).
But that's the price a Minneapolis gallery in the US is asking for A Walk In The Woods — the first of more than 400 paintings Ross produced on-air for his PBS series The Joy Of Painting.
A Walk in the Woods was Bob Ross' first painting for his iconic TV show.
(AP Photo: Mark Vancleave)
"It is season one, episode one of what you would call the rookie card for Bob Ross," Ryan Nelson, who owns the gallery, Modern Artifact, said of the work created in the show's debut in 1983.
He says he doesn't expect a quick sale given the high asking price, which he sees as an opportunity to display the painting for a larger audience.
"What this piece represents is the people's artist," Mr Nelson says.

"This isn't an institution that's telling you that Bob Ross is great. It's not some high-brow gallery telling you that Bob Ross is great. This is the masses, the population in the world that are saying that Bob Ross is great."
On that first show, Ross — sporting his beloved perm, full beard and unbuttoned shirt — stressed that painting didn't need to be pretentious:
Ross, who died in 1995, hosted the show until 1994.

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

image.altText: Von der Leyen can be seen in focus in between soldiers

props.synopsis: A former musician who was once forced to go into hiding from terrorists, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's path to power has been an incredible journey.

title.children: How a young girl destined to become a 'housewife at the side of a powerful man' instead grew up to lead Europe through crisis

props.synopsis: The AFL's preliminary finals weekend pits the league's two most consistent teams of the year — Collingwood and Brisbane — with the most in-form challengers — GWS and Carlton. Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson break down how the games will be won and lost.

title.children: The leaders or the challengers? How two massive AFL preliminary finals will be decided

image.altText: Firefighters extinguishing fire in the bush

props.synopsis: The Rural Fire Service says conditions are easing in parts of NSW after more than 100 fires flared over the past three days during heatwave conditions.

title.children: Cool reprieve for NSW after more than 100 fires burned during heatwave

image.altText: A jar of honey is filled using an automatic dispenser

props.synopsis: Research into varroa mite is expected to surge after Australia waved the white flag in its fight to eradicate the pest from New South Wales, a decision that is also expected to increase beekeeping costs.

title.children: Will living with varroa mite make Australian honey and food more expensive?

image.altText: Barnaby Joyce speaks at a press conference, where journalists hold microphones. Other politicians stand behind him.

props.synopsis: An unlikely coalition of Australian parliamentarians converges on Washington to lobby US decision-makers to drop the legal pursuit of Julian Assange and grant his freedom by Christmas.

title.children: 'We came here to get a resolution': Australian MPs lobby Washington for Assange's freedom

image.altText: The silhouette of a firefighter is seen in front of a large bushfire burning high into trees.

props.synopsis: Catastrophic fire danger warnings have been issued in parts of Australia already as it enters a hotter and drier than average climate pattern. If the fire season has taken you by surprise, here's a reminder of how the warning system works.

title.children: What makes a bushfire alert 'catastrophic', and how should you respond?

image.altText: a man in an office with documents

props.synopsis: Former chair of the ACCC to oversee an inquiry into Price Gouging and Unfair Pricing Practices, while a fall on Wall Street sends Australian stocks lower today. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: Former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging, US Fed holds interest rates steady, ASX falls

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "While we are really feeling this in the cities, it is the regional and rural areas suffer most at a time of crisis, " Ms Thistleton told the inquiry. "When you already have decreased competition, the increased costs of getting fruit and vegetables transported to these areas mean the prices become unmanageable for anyone. On top of that in many remote and indigenous communities', price gouging has just become a really unfortunate part of every day life." She pointed to some research by the National Indigenous Australians Agency that people in those communities are paying up to 40 per cent more for supermarket goods than people in capital cities. Some example she gave were a box of cornflakes for $12 and a small jar of vegemite for $13.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional and rural areas suffer most at a time of crisis

children.content: "While we are really feeling this in the cities, it is the
regional and rural areas suffer most at a time of crisis,
" Ms Thistleton told the inquiry.
"When you already have decreased competition, the increased costs of getting fruit and vegetables transported to these areas mean the prices become unmanageable for anyone.
On top of that in many remote and indigenous communities', price gouging has just become a really unfortunate part of every day life."
She pointed to some research by the
National Indigenous Australians Agency
that people in those communities are
paying up to 40 per cent more
for supermarket goods than people in capital cities.
Some example she gave were a box of cornflakes for $12 and a small jar of vegemite for $13.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ms Thistleton told the inquiry their research has found that in the past decade extreme weather has costs households about $880 a year. That's of course an average across all households in Australia — some have had it much worse, others have not. "McKell's predictions show t his would rise to about $2,500 by 2050, per household ." She said that would be on top of rising fuel and food prices. "Governments have spent far more money on recovery than on resilience."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Impact of extreme weather on cost of living

children.content: Ms Thistleton told the inquiry their research has found that in the past decade
extreme weather has costs households about $880 a year
That's of course an average across all households in Australia — some have had it much worse, others have not.
"McKell's predictions show t
his would rise to about $2,500 by 2050, per household
She said that would be on top of rising fuel and food prices.
"Governments have spent far more money on recovery than on resilience."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ms Thistleton says people are getting "quite desperate". She queried why Australia doesn't have price gouging laws in place, like other countries, such as the US do. Ms Thistleton says "this environment where we've got profits driving inflation and consumers copping higher interest rates while they're paying the higher price, that doesn't pass the vibe check ".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'People are getting quite desperate': McKell Institute

image.altText: Elon Musks' face is pictured behind the logo for Neuralink.

props.synopsis: Elon Musk's brain-chip startup Neuralink says it will begin recruiting for the first human trial of its brain implant for paralysis patients after receiving approval from an independent review board.

image.altText: A woman looks out to the distance wearing a black wide brimmed hat.
